content:
Thunderbird の問題を診断するには、次のいずれかを試してください:

アドオンを無効にして Thunderbird を再起動します (Thunderbird セーフモード)。[ヘルプ] メニューの [アドオンを無効にして再起動] をクリックします。Thunderbird が正常に動作する場合は、アドオンまたはテーマが通常の動作を妨げています。違反者を見つけるまで、一度に1つずつアドオンを再度有効にする必要があります。 オペレーティングシステムをセーフモードで再起動し、ネットワークを使用します。これにより、インターネット接続を有効にしながらコンピューターを起動するために必要な非常に基本的なもののみが読み込まれます。セーフモードで起動する方法については、オペレーティングシステムをクリックしてください:Windows 10、Windows 8、Windows 7、Windows Vista、Windows XP、OSX オペレーティング システムのセーフ モードで問題が解決した場合は、コンピューターに問題の原因となっている他のソフトウェアがあります。可能性には、AVスキャン、ウイルス/マルウェア、プログラムの更新などのバックグラウンドダウンロードが含まれますが、これらに限定されません。

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-crashes Greetings Firefox volunteer
creator: Googlethunderbird

content: Some email providers default to a specific draft folder, possibly called Drafts or Draft, which may be different from from what Thunderbird defined. Check first to see which one is being used. The other one can sometimes be deleted from within Thunderbird and, if that doesn't work, try exiting thunderbird and deleting from within profile folder, where it would be at imapmail\<accountname> or Mail\<POPaccountname>
creator: davidsk

content: You might consider creating a filter that looks for your email account in FROM and also in TO and delete them.
creator: davidsk

content:
I get plenty of those types of bogus mail. You are wary of using your email address to set up as spam. I agree because if you are using an imap account then that sort of information - put in Spam folder - is also then known by the server and it can be used to 'complain' about the email address. Thus you could inadvertantly end up getting your own email address on server spam filters.

In addition you do need to careful that you do not end up wth a filter that does not realise the From is from you testing something. Never use TO your email address because everything you get is TO you.

I have found that in many cases there is a 'Repy-to' which maybe a common factor and can be used in the filter. Sometimes you can use the 'Subject' content in a filter. maybe there is the original IP address in the 'Received by' headers but again you need to be careful because they maybe using a VPN, so not exactly reliable.

Select email - click on 'More' and select 'View Source' OR Close the Message Pane - select email in list to highlight - View > Message Source or (Ctrl+U) This offers more data on what is contained in the email.


Sometimes this is something that's temporary - the nefarious person is looking for people to respond or click on something in the email which triggers some remote content in email. Just make sure you have the default do not allow remote content selected - Thunderbird does set that by default. Don't click on anything that may be in that email. Basically, if you know it's not you then just delete it. They usually get bored after a while when there is no response.

content:
Do you have your outgoing server name set to smtp.office365.com with connection security set to STARTTLS and authentication method set to oAth?

I find most folks with issues are either not using oauth, or have not changed the server name to allow oauth. (a Thunderbird restart is required after changing the server name to make oauth an option in the list of authentication methods.)
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Thank you Matt I managed to solve it with your help. I tried smtp.office365.com but I don't have 365 and it didn't work so I reverted back to my original smtp-mail.outlook along with part of your advice of using Connection Security STARTTLS plus Authorisation method OAuth2 (which is mine) and low and behold it worked and I tested sending at least 6 emails with that format. When I had a close look the Server Port had changed to 143 and for quite a few years had been 993. Thanks Pat

content:
Scooter said
The current release is 136.0.

We still support the ESR branch for the full year it is current plus a point release and as the ESR Branch has not been deprecated there will be another one next year.

This Support Volunteer is unlikely to be jumping on the bleeding edge with Monthly releases until they have proven themselves to be actually stable. I find V128 to be less than impressive with regard to reliability and stability with frequent freezes and odd connectivity issues on startup that have not been addressed over multiple ESR releases. I see no point in moving to a less tested environment and having more issues. ESR releases are plagued with xxx.X.1 and xxx.X.2 point releases because the standards being applied are seeing serious defects in release software. Perhaps the delay in getting these new half baked features will be a godsend because once you install Monthly, there is no going back to your ESR version with you existing profile without pain. Not can you go back to last months release any easier.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Ok the fundamental idea of mailing lists in Thunderbird was reexamined in the changing of the database used to store contacts

SO historically the mailing list contained the contact. If they appeared somewhere else, that was a different entry. In the new system contacts are links to contacts in the address book, so if you change the phone number from within the address list the base record is updates as that is what is in the address book, not another contact.

So you can drag and drop contacts between address books. You can drag and drop contact within an address book to a mailing list and they will appear there but the base record will still appear in the address book.v It also makes it possible for the same contact to be in multiple mailing lists, like congregation, deacons and Youth Club in a religious type context. Deleting an entry in a mailing list does not delete the contact, only their membership of the list.

If you can not drag contact between address books, or drag contacts within an address book to a list in that address book, I suggest you try restarting Thunderbird in Troubleshooting mode from the help menu as it works for me.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Matt, thanks for your quick response. I can drag a contact, or multiple contacts (so long as I make sure what I'm dragging doesn't include the target mailing list itself), from an address book to a mailing list *within that address book* but I'm afraid that doesn't help, or at least I can't see how it helps. I have a bunch of addresses, and I want to avoid the tedious, and error-prone, process of having to scroll through, find, and select each individual contact to drag them to the mailing list in which I need them to be.

The existing mailing lists are all within one address book. I could import the new addresses into that address book, but then they'd just be mixed in with all the existing addresses there and I'd be back to tedious and error prone. And I can import them into a new address book, where they'll be separate like I need them initially, and put them into a mailing list in that address book, but then I can't drag them from either that address book or that mailing list into a mailing list in another address book - back to the tedious again.

I get the idea of a mailing list being a view into an address book, rather than a separate set of contacts, and speaking as a coder, I might kinda like it - if I weren't having so much trouble with it as a user. But it seems very reasonable to want to import such a view from an outside file, and to be able to drag those views between address books, so long as the contacts in the view exist in the target address book. I can't be the only person who needs to verify and confirm batches of new addresses before adding them to existing mailing lists.
creator: samarak

content:
samarak said
I can't be the only person who needs to verify and confirm batches of new addresses before adding them to existing mailing lists.

YOu might be getting close. With the restrictions most of the mail providers are bringing in with regards to volues of mail almost everyone with serious mailing list needs has moved to mailhouses. Even the Thunderbird project uses one. List I checked the project used the services of mailchimp

But for the purposes of verifying folk for inclusion, I would tend to use something like mailmerge for most of my group mailing needs and it works with the CSV file as well as address books and mailing lists. It also obviates the risks associated with the necessity placing the list in BCC instead of CC or to and breaching the European privacy laws by accident. But I have been using mail merge in one form or another since Word V2 for Windows and AmiPro came across my desk, in the 1980s I guess it was, to create personalized correspondence.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
When I say verify I mean to send them an actual email to confirm that we have their address entered correctly, in which I attempt to confirm that they do want to receive email from us going forward. Many of these are people who signed up on paper at an event, so there's a considerable chance of transcription error by the time I get the address. And a few will have reconsidered and decided they don't want to hear from us after all. Mail merge may let me do that, but how does it help me get those addresses into the existing mailing list once they've been verified in a single mass operation - not one by one? (I've used mail merge in other software - Word, Excel, etc. - but not TB.)

We're trying to avoid the expense associated with the mailhouses - *small* non-profit. We send a couple of dozen emails a year.

It seems crazy that there's no way to create a mailing list from a CSV file in a selected address book, and that there's no way to merge a mailing list into another in a different address book. Both seem like serious omissions.
creator: samarak

content: Being discussed here https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1498480
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I went here looking for instructions. https://www.namecheap.com/support/knowledgebase/article.aspx/1179/2175/general-private-email-configuration-for-mail-clients-and-mobile-devices/

Based on that you need to be using port 587 for TLS/STARTTLS Despite Thunderbird calling the entry SSL/TLS SSL has in fact been disabled in Thunderbird for years. It was officially deprecated in 2015 and Thunderbird disabled support at that time if memory serves me correctly. So SSL/TLS has in fact been TLS since then.
creator: MattAuSupport
